description: London's first dedicated public art walk, following the waterways & line of the Greenwich Meridian between Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park & The O2. This free outdoor exhibition programme offers a journey through a dynamic urban landscape.

factsheet.heading: More information
paragraphs: Connecting three boroughs (Newham, Tower Hamlets and Greenwich) and following the Greenwich Meridian, The Line runs between Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park and The O2. It offers a journey through a dynamic urban landscape where everyone can explore art, nature and heritage for free.

The Line presents an evolving programme of art installations, projects and events and features over 20 artists, including Larry Achiampong, Rana Begum, Tracey Emin, Antony Gormley and Serge Attukwei Clottey.

Co-founded by Megan Piper and the late regeneration expert Clive Dutton OBE (1953-2015), The Line’s mission is to connect communities and inspire individuals, to support health and wellbeing and provide engaging, cross-curricular educational opportunities.

factsheet.heading: Map and Bloomberg Connects app
paragraphs:
Accompany your visit with The Line's digital guide on the free Bloomberg Connects app. Listen directly to the artists talking about their works. Discover more about the history and architecture on the route as Bill Nighy takes you on a guided tour. Take a moment for yourself with three specially commissioned mindfulness guides and explore the wildlife with The Living Line nature guide. 
https://www.bloombergconnects.org/
You can also use our interactive map to plan your self-guided visit and explore points of interest - architectural, historical, natural - along the route, as well as refreshment stops.

factsheet.heading: For families
paragraphs:
Fun for all ages! Download our activity packs to enjoy on the route or at home: 
'The Living Line' activity pack celebrating the 146m-long nature illustration on The Line at Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park. 
'Make The Line' features fun activities designed and produced by The Line's artists.
The House of Fairy Tales's 'Walk The Line' is a booklet full of inspirational ideas and tales. 
https://the-line.org/learning/for-families/

factsheet.heading: Visitor information
paragraphs: The Line is three miles as the crow flies however it is along winding waterways, so it takes around four hours to complete the entire route. You can walk The Line in one go or visit different sections on different days - it is constantly changing, depending on the tide, time of day and season.

There are two sections where you need to pay to travel: North Greenwich and the Royal Docks are connected by the Emirates Air Line, a cable car that takes you over the Thames. The Royal Docks and Cody Dock are connected by a short DLR journey (Royal Victoria to Star Lane) - change at Canning Town to visit Rana Begum's No. 1104 Catching Colour at London City Island.

There is one section on the River Lea between the House Mill and Twelvetrees Bridge that isn’t accessible for disabled users, however we have highlighted an alternative route on our downloadable map that cuts out the ramps that aren’t DDA compliant and offers a fully accessible journey.
Go to https://the-line.org/visitor-info/ for a map and downloadable written directions.

name: The Line - London's public art walk
